stem: A 22-year-old client is admitted to the ICU following an acute spinal cord injury at the T2 level. Based on the documentation in the Post-Injury Hemodynamic Flowsheet tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Monitoring for shock states post-SCI.
Background: T2 vertebral fracture with cord transection.
Assessment: Client has warm, dry extremities and is increasingly lethargic.
Recommendation: Aggressive hemodynamic support.

tabs.title: Post-Injury Hemodynamic Flowsheet
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Blood Pressure78/42 mmHgHypotension
Heart Rate44 bpmBradycardia
Skin StatusWarm; Pink; Dry below injuryMassive Vasodilation
CVP2 mmHg (Low)Low filling pressure

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 78/42, HR 44, RR 14, T 97.4Â°F. Urine output 15mL/hr.

actionOptions.text: Administer IV fluids (0.9% NS) as prescribed
Administer IV Atropine or Vasopressors (Norepinephrine) as prescribed
Strictly withhold all fluids until the heart rate increases
Apply cooling blankets to treat the warm skin

parameterOptions.text: Continuous blood pressure and MAP monitoring
Continuous heart rate and cardiac rhythm assessment
Presence of deep tendon reflexes and sensation

rationale.correct: This is Neurogenic Shock (c2), characterized by the 'Unnatural Triad': Hypotension, Bradycardia (HR 44), and Warm/Dry skin (due to massive vasodilation below the injury). In every other type of shock, the body compensates with Tachycardia and cold skin. Priority actions are to fill the 'dilated' tank with fluids (a1) and use vasopressors/atropine (a2) to increase the HR and vascular tone. Monitoring Vitals (p1) and HR (p2) is the standard for titration.
clinicalPearls: Neurogenic shock is a VASCULAR problem (loss of sympathetic tone). Spinal shock is a REFLEX problem (loss of motor/sensory function). They can occur together, but only neurogenic shock is life-threatening.
Poikilothermia (taking on the environment's temp) is common because the client cannot shiver or sweat below the injury.
The warm/dry skin distinguishes this from hypovolemic shock, where the skin is cold/clammy.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the patient has hypovolemic shock because the BP is low.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Look at the heart rate! If the HR is LOW while the BP is LOW, it's neurogenic shock. If the HR is HIGH, it's hypovolemic/septic shock.
